ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Analysis of electro-active regions and conductivity of BaMnO3 ceramic by impedance spectroscopy

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Materials Research Laboratory, Institute of Physics and Electronics
Micro and Nano Devices Group, Department of Metallurgy and Materials Engineering
Affiliation.OrgName: Pakistan Institute of Engineering and Applied Sciences (PIEAS)

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Polycrystalline BaMnO3 ceramic powders were prepared using the conventional mixed oxide route accompanied with several milling processes. Single phase formation was verified by recording the X-ray diffraction pattern of the powder as well as sintered pellet at room temperature. Scanning electron micrograph and energy dispersive X-ray spectrum of cross-sectional view have shown that sintered pellet is highly porous and contains only Ba, Mn and O elements, respectively. Analysis of impedance spectroscopy was carried out via the complex impedance and complex modulus formalisms. These results have shown that BaMnO3 behave as semiconducting material. Furthermore, as a consequence of electrically inhomogeneous nature of the sample, it was observed that the electroactive regions (such as grain, grain boundary and sample-electrode interface) are overlapped in the applied frequency domain with dominant grain boundary effect. An equivalent circuit model (R g C g)(R gb Q gb)(R e Q e) was employed to fit the temperature dependent impedance spectroscopy data. Study of grain and grain boundary conductivities suggest that grains are more conductive than grain boundaries and conduction mechanism followed correlated barrier hopping (CBH) model.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: For technologically potential applications, it is important to improve efficiency of existing materials or synthesize new materials by focusing on new routes of synthesis and their processing conditions followed by careful investigation of structural, morphological, magnetic and electrical properties through sophisticated techniques. Materials of perovskite-related structure such as manganites, with formula AMnO3 is an important family of ceramics that have versatile structural and promising electrical and magnetic properties [1, 2]. Here “A” and “Mn” represent the corner and body centered cations, respectively, while “O” represents anion occupied at the face centered position of the unit cell. These manganites are chemically and thermally stable at high temperatures and have found some suitable industrial applications. Barium manganate (BaMnO3) is one of the members of manganites sub-family. It possesses different hexagonal (H) and rhombohedral (R) structures such as 2H, 4H, 6H, …, 15R, 21R, etc., which are stable at different sintering temperatures investigated by Negas, T. and Roth, R.S. [3]. Parras, M. et al. [4] and Gonzalez-Calbet, J.M. et al. [5] have studied the microstructure of different phases of this material. Recently, this material has been studied as an efficient candidate of NO direct decomposition into nitrogen (N2) and oxygen (O2) [6], hydrogen storage material as a result of hydrogen uptake at atmospheric pressure [7] and gas sensor at different temperatures under various concentrations of O2 [8].

However, to find some practical applications of this material it is necessary to explore its properties (such as electrical or magnetic properties, etc.). In case of electrical characterizations an impedance spectroscopy (IS) was employed to explore the effect of different electro-active regions. Impedance spectroscopy is a powerful technique used to investigate the electrical microstructures of materials both qualitatively and quantitatively [9]. In this technique, a suitable range of frequency of a small AC signal is applied to the materials and impedance spectra are measured at various low and/or high temperatures. The analysis of such impedance spectra is then used to explore the properties of materials.

In this report the electrical properties of barium manganate ceramic are investigated through complex impedance (Z ∗) and modulus (M ∗) formalisms to identify the different electro-active regions in ceramics (i.e., grain, grain boundary and electrode effects). This study also includes the analysis of ac conductivity as a function of frequency (20 Hz–2 MHz) and temperature (300–370 K) to investigate the possible operating conduction mechanism in this material. Four different types of formalisms that uses for data analysis in complex spectroscopy (CS) are: complex impedance Z ∗, complex admittance Y ∗, complex permittivity ε ∗ and complex modulus M ∗. In this spectroscopy one or more RC circuits (with R and C in parallel combinations) in series combinations are employed to explore the realistic view of the impedance of the electrode-sample-electrode system whose results are most probably unambiguous [10].

Section2.Heading: Synthesis and processing
Section2.Para: BaCO3 (Sigma-Aldrich, purity≥99 %) and MnO2 (Sigma-Aldrich, purity≥99 %) were used as starting materials for the synthesis of BaMnO3 by conventional mixed oxide route. Prior to mixing the raw materials in stoichiometric amount (with molar ratio 1:1), BaCO3 and MnO2 were dried at 180 °C and 500 °C overnight, respectively, in oven/furnace to eliminate water contents. The weighed raw materials (BaCO3 and MnO2) were mixed with distilled water in a polyethylene bottle (jar) of 250 ml, containing cylindrical shaped magnesia-doped zirconia media. This mixture was then milled for 24 hours to get homogenous mixture of almost same diameter particles of different precursors. After wet sieving, the milled slurry was dried in oven at 80 °C for 30 hours, followed by grinding and then sieved by a 250 μm stainless steel (SS) sieve to get fine powder. The acquired fine powder was pre-heated at 1000 °C for 5 hours at ramp rates of 5 °C/min. After taking X-ray diffraction pattern, the reacted powders were re-milled, wet sieved, dried and finally dry sieved for good sinterability.

Section2.Heading: Pelletisation and sintering
Section2.Para: The fine powders were then pressed in cylindrical green pellets of ∼2 mm thickness using a SS die of 10 mm diameter by applying a uniaxial load of 0.4 tons for 2 min. Cracks were observed in pellets fired at high temperatures. To avoid these cracks, prior to sintering, green pellets were more compacted by applying a 240 MPa isostatic pressure for 1–2 min using cold isostatic press (CIP). After CIP, these compacted green pellets were sintered in tube furnace at 1300 °C for a dwell time of 5 h with heating ramp rate of 2 °C per minute and temperature cooling rate of 1 °C per minute.

Section2.Heading: Characterizations
Section2.Para: For phase analysis powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern was taken using Philips PW1825 X-ray Diffractometer, with Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.5406 Å), operated at 40 kV and 30 mA. Morphology and composition analysis of un-etched and thermally etched pellets were taken using scanning electron microscope (SEM), LEO-4401, and electron probe micro-analyzer (EPMA) attached with SEM, respectively. Prior to low temperature impedance data measurement, both surfaces of pellet were polished using SiC paper, followed by painting with gold paste. After painting, pellets were dried at 200 °C and then fired at 800 °C for 2 h to burn off the organics contained in the Au paste. Both the heating and cooling ramp rates of furnace were kept as 10 °C/min. Impedance data was recorded at an applied AC voltage of 100 mV using impedance analyzer (Agilent E4980A, Agilent, USA). Frequency was varied from 20 Hz to 2 MHz while temperature was changed from 300–370 K with a step of 10 K.

Section2.Heading: XRD, SEM and EDX analysis
Section2.Para:
Figure 1(a) shows the X-ray diffraction pattern of crushed pellet of barium manganate sintered at 1300 °C for 5 hours. XRD pattern was indexed with space group
$R \overline{3} m$ . All peaks were successfully index and matched with standard JCPDS card # 72-1754 (166) indicating that powders consist of single phase polycrystalline BaMnO3 compound. A typical scanning electron micrograph (cross-sectional view) of a BaMnO3 pellet sintered in air at 1300 °C for 5 h is shown in Fig. 1(b). Similar micrograph was observed for thermally etched pellet (polished and heat treated to 90 % of its sintering temperature for 30 min). From SEM micrograph it is noteworthy that BaMnO3 pellet is consisting of fine equiaxed grains of ∼2 μm. Figure 1(b) also reveals that the sintered pellet possessed highly porous nature with formation of necking between grains.
Fig. 1
Three different features of BaMnO3 sample are shown in this figure. (a) XRD pattern of barium manganate powder reacted at 1300 °C for dwell time of 5 h, (b) SEM micrograph showing the surface view of thermally etched pellet, and (c) EDX spectrum of pellet

For chemical composition analysis of the BaMnO3 pellet, energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectrum is shown in Fig. 1(c). EDX result shows only barium, manganese, and oxygen elements, indicating the absence of any impurity in the sample under investigation. To authenticate our results Archimedes principle was employed to measure the sintered pellet density (in water medium) and results were compared with reported theoretical density of investigating material. It was found that the experimental density (5.89 g/cm3) was 97.42 % of the theoretical density (6.044 g/cm3). This indicates that the high degree of porosity as observed in the pellet is the inherent property of this material.

Section2.Heading: Impedance spectroscopy (IS) analysis
Section2.Para:
Figure 2 illustrates the Nyquist plots for BaMnO3 sample at various temperatures ranges from 300 to 370 K. In these plots frequency is directed from high Z′-intercept towards low Z′-intercept point (i.e., at the origin). At low frequency the intersection of Nyquist plots with Z′-axis provides the total resistance of the sample. At each temperature the Nyquist plot shows overlapped and depressed semicircular arcs with center lying below the Z′-axis. This specify two distinct features of the sample: (i) the overlapped nature of the semicircular arcs demonstrate that at each temperature more than one relaxation phenomena (associated with different electroactive regions) exist in our material. The associated difference in the relaxation times, τ=RC (where R and C are the resistor and capacitor, respectively) is very small. (ii) The depressed nature of the arcs indicates the non-ideal Debye type behavior of the sample. This non-ideal behavior may be due to several factors including oxygen vacancies as a result of non-stoichiometric distribution of oxygen, dangling bonds at grain boundaries, grains orientation, stress-strain phenomena in the lattice etc. [10]. This non-ideal behavior of the sample will be explored later on from the fitting results of impedance data using ZView software. Furthermore, as temperature increases the radius of each semicircular arc was found to decrease accordingly. This illustrates that resistivity of the sample decreases by increasing the temperature of BaMnO3 sample which is the characteristic of semiconducting materials.
Fig. 2
Plot of real (Z′) and imaginary (Z″) components of impedance (Z ∗) at different temperatures

Figure 3(a) and 3(b) show the plots of real (Z′) and imaginary components (Z″) of complex impedance (Z ∗) with frequency, respectively, measured at different temperatures. Figure 3(a) shows that for all temperatures Z′ decreases with increasing frequency. The dispersion in Z′ is fast at lower frequencies as a result of significant effect of polarization (such as interfacial polarization and Debye type orientational polarization of dipoles) [11, 12] of the material. While, due to rotational displacements of the dipoles, dispersion in Z′ becomes almost independent at higher frequencies. Also, at lower frequencies, the magnitude of Z′ decreases with increasing temperature. This indicates that the AC conductivity of the sample has been increased as a result of decrease in the resistance of different electro-active regions (such as grains, grain boundaries, surface layers, sample-electrode effects, etc.) in the sample [9]. However, in Fig. 3(a), at high frequency (>105 Hz) Z′ vs. log(f) plots at various temperatures amalgamate which may be due to the reduction in barrier properties followed by the release of space charges in the investigating material.
Fig. 3
Plots of experimental data of (a) Z′ versus log of frequency and (b) −Z″ versus log of frequency at different temperatures

The loss spectrum (−Z″ vs. log(f)), as shown in Fig. 3(b), is used to explore some important characteristics of ceramics such as (i) it is used for the estimation of relaxation frequencies f r or f max (=(2πτ)−1, where “τ” is called the relaxation time) due to different electro-active regions in the ceramics. (ii) The magnitude of peak maximum (
$Z''_{\max}$ ) decreases with rising temperature indicating a decrease in sample resistivity which is a typical behavior of semiconductor materials. (iii) The shift and broadening of the peak can be explained in term of grain boundaries. Loss spectrum peak shifts to higher frequency side with temperature, suggesting accumulation of space charge in BaMnO3 at grain boundaries [13]. (iv) Increase in the peak’s broadening with raising temperature is an indication of inhomogenity of the sample. Also, the asymmetrical nature of the peaks suggests the non-Debye type behavior of our sample. From the above discussion it is noteworthy that to model the IS data for such materials, in the studied temperature regime, more than one RC circuits will be used in the equivalent circuit.

Recently, Satapathy et al. [14] studied the ferroelectric behavior of 2H–BaMnO3. In their work, they have investigated the presence of some Mn+3 cations along with Mn+4 cations which produce disorder in the crystal lattice of this material. In view of these results, we can understand the trend of our impedance results with temperature that Mn4+ will reduce and form Mn3+ which results in the creation of oxygen vacancies. The existence of Mn4+ and Mn3+ will facilitate the hopping of carriers in the investigating material [15].

In Fig. 3(b), at each temperature, low resistive phenomena exist at lower frequencies which are suppressed by the high resistive region in the material. To clarify this effect, we have re-plotted the data at 310 K on log–log scale, as shown in the inset in Fig. 3(b). It is clear from the figure shown in the inset that a peak exists at low frequency which corresponds to some relaxation phenomena in the material and we will discuss it later. The high frequency peak was named as “Peak 1” while that exist at low frequency is denoted by “Peak 2”.

At the Debye peak maxima the product of RC and ω max is always equal to unity. Therefore, in general, the Debye peak maximum,
$Z''_{\max}$ (=R/2), is used to calculate resistance, R, while capacitance, C, is determined by substituting the value of f max (i.e., obtained from the peak position) in the expression, C=1/(2πf max R). Using these expression, the associated R and C with peak 1 and 2, at 310 K, have values R 1=166.93 kΩ, C 1=1.9×10−11 F and R 2=43.28 kΩ, C 2=6.83×10−7 F, respectively. As, in Z″ vs. log(f) plot, the impedance response is dominated by the more resistive region in the material, therefore, main reason for the suppression of the low frequency peak in Fig. 3(b) is because of low value of R 2 than R 1. Therefore, C 1 represents grain boundary (GB) capacitance while C 2 denotes the electrode capacitance. The value of capacitance C 1 is very low as compared to the conventional GB response (i.e., 10−11–10−8 F) [16], which is due to the porous nature of our material as shown in the SEM micrograph in Fig. 1(b) [17].

For dominant peak 1, grain boundary conductivity σ gb (=1/R) was calculated at different temperatures. Arrhenius plot of σ gb is shown in Fig. 4. GB activation energy was calculated from the slope of linear fit in the data points. The GB has E a=0.29 eV with an error of ±0.02. For peak 1, the value of peak position, f max, was used to evaluate GB relaxation time, τ (=(2πf max)−1), followed by activation energy. Figure 5 shows the logarithmic plot of τ with inverse of absolute temperature. It is clear that ln(τ) varies linearly with T −1 and obeys the Arrhenius law as shown in the following Eq. (1). 1
$$ \tau = \tau_{0}\exp (-E_{\mathrm{a}}/k_{\beta}T) $$ where τ 0, E a, k
β , and “T” are the pre-exponential factor, the activation energy of thermally activated process in the material, Boltzmann constant and the absolute temperature, respectively.
Fig. 4
Arrhenius plot of grain boundary conductivity (extracted from Z″ plots)
Fig. 5
Logarithmic plot of relaxation time (τ) with inverse of temperature (T −1)

Figure 5 indicates a decrease in the relaxation time as temperature of the sample increases. Activation energy was evaluated from the slope of linear fit in the data points. The GB activation energy was found to be 0.31 eV±0.12.

Figure 6 shows the combine impedance (−Z″) and modulus (M″/ε 0) spectroscopic plots as a function of frequency at two different temperatures, i.e., at 300 K and 370 K. The main advantage of using modulus spectroscopy is that, in this formalism the information about the electrode effect is suppressed and one can easily study the intrinsic effect of the sample that can originate from electro-active region (i.e., grain) in the sample. This formalism is also helpful to study the conductivity relaxation time. Sinclair et al. [18] proposed that a combine plot of Z″ vs. log(f) and M″/ε 0 vs. log(f) is used to notice the effect of the largest resistor and the smallest capacitor. According to them, for a particular RC circuit element, −Z″ and M″/ε 0 peaks on the frequency scale should be coincident. In Fig. 6(a), at 300 K, Z″ vs. log(f) plot shows a single peak which shifts towards high frequency with increase of temperature as shown in Fig. 6(b). In M″/ε 0 vs. log(f) spectrum an onset of peak can be seen at 300 K which is not fully formed/or visible. With increasing temperature onset of M″/ε 0 peak shifts towards high frequency as shown in Fig. 6(b). This is due to the limitation of available experimental frequency range i.e., 20 Hz–2 MHz and we are not getting the bulk information with increasing temperature. This issue can be solved by increasing the frequency range which is system limitation. As in Fig. 6 both peaks are located at different frequencies and their peak maxima are separated by more than one order of magnitude. It means that these Debye peaks represent two different electro-active regions in the material. At 300 K, the capacitance values were found to have values in nano-Farad (nF) and pico-Farad (pF) as calculated from the peaks in −Z″ vs. log(f) and M″/ε 0 vs. log(f) plots, respectively. On the basis of capacitance values these two electro-active regions were assign names as grain boundary and grain as shown in Fig. 6.
Fig. 6
Plots of imaginary parts of impedance (Z″) and modulus (M″) as a function of frequency at (a) 300 K, and (b) 370 K

In materials (especially electrically inhomogeneous), when the impedance response of one electro-active region overlaps with the response of other electro-active region in the applied frequency domain, a composite response is generated in the impedance spectrum. Equivalent circuit analysis is then an important alternative source employed to isolate the response of different electro-active regions and characterize them separately. From Nyquist plot, in Fig. 2, and loss spectrum, in Fig. 3, it is difficult to distinguish the bulk effect (at high frequency) and electrode effect (at low frequency) from dominant grain boundary effect (at intermediate frequency). Therefore, it is necessary to model the data to analyze and separate these effects using an appropriate equivalent circuit model.

From visual inspection of Fig. 2 we have tried different equivalent circuit models (ECMs) such as (R 1 C 1)(R 2 C 2), (R 1 C 1)(R 2 Q 2) and (R 1 Q 1)(R 2 Q 2) to fit the impedance data measured at different temperatures. In these ECMs, one circuit was used for grain boundary while second circuit represents the electrode effect. Fitting analysis of these ECMs has shown disagreement with experimental results most probably at the high frequency region. This indicates that the high frequency region is the outcome of complex response of more than one electro-active region in the sample. Therefore, we added a third RC circuit to the ECM to fit the impedance data at different temperatures. The final equivalent circuit model employed for modeling the impedance data is (R 1 C 1)(R 2 Q 2)(R 3 Q 3) and diagrammatically it is shown in Fig. 7. Here, R 1, R 2 and R 3 represent the resistance of circuit 1, 2 and 3 of equivalent circuit, respectively, while C 1, Q 2 and Q 3 denote the capacitance and constant phase element. All these parameters will be assigned to different electro-active regions of electrode-sample-electrode system in the following paragraph. “Q” is used to show the deviation of capacitor form its ideal behavior. The capacitance of “Q” is obtained from the expression, C=R (1−n)/n
Q 1/n , where the value of parameter “n” lies between 0 and 1. If n=1, the constant phase element will behave as a pure capacitor and for n=0 it acts as a pure resistor.
Fig. 7
Equivalent circuit model (R 1 C 1)(R 2 Q 2)(R 3 Q 3) used to distinguish different electro-active regions

Figure 8 shows combine plot of experimental data and fitted results. The solid black lines represent the fitted results while the colored open symbols stand for experimental data points. Figure 8(a) shows Nyquist plots while Fig. 8(b) and 8(c) show the experimental and fitted results of |Z| and theta as a function of frequency at four different temperatures (i.e., 300, 320, 340 and 370 K). Figure 8 demonstrates that the fitted results are well matched with experimental data. This indicates that the equivalent circuit model adopted for modeling the experimental data in ZView software is the best one.
Fig. 8
Plots of fitted and experimental data of (a) −Z″ versus Z′, (b) |Z| versus frequency on log–log scale and (c) theta versus frequency (on log scale) at four different temperatures

The fitted values of all components in the equivalent circuit model at different temperatures are tabulated in Table 1. From Table 1 it is clear that R 2>R 3 and R 2≫R 1. This indicates that circuit R 2 Q 2 represents the most resistive part of the sample while circuit R 1 C 1 stands for less resistive region of the system under investigation. Since, R 2 is greater than R 1 and R 3, therefore, it represents the dominant peak 1 at intermediate frequency and is responsible for the suppression of other effects of the system at low and high frequencies as shown in Fig. 3(b). From the close inspection of the associated capacitance values, circuit R 1 C 1, R 2 Q 2 and R 3 Q 3 were assigned to grain/bulk, grain boundary and electrode electro-active regions of the system, respectively. Parameters R 1, R 2 and R 3 are now represented by R b, R gb and R e while C 1, C 2 and C 3 (where C 2 and C 3 were extracted from Q 2 and Q 3) are denoted by C b, C gb and C e, respectively.
Table 1
Values of fitted parameters extracted from (R 1 C 1)(R 2 Q 2)(R 3 Q 3) equivalent circuit model of the impedance data at different temperatures
Frequency
E a (eV)
25 Hz
0.305
1 kHz
0.287
100 kHz
0.227
2 MHz
0.186

Variation of bulk, grain boundary, and electrode capacitance (i.e., C b, C gb, and C e) with temperature are shown in Fig. 9. C b, C gb and C e have almost constant trends with temperature. For electrode, C e is slightly reduced with increasing temperature according to our expectation. This indicates that at sample-electrode interface mobility of the carriers has been increased as a result of reduction in barrier height with rise of temperature.
Fig. 9
Plot of bulk (C 1), grain boundary (C 2), and electrode (C 3) capacitance as a function of temperature

Figure 10 shows Arrhenius plots of bulk, grain boundary, and electrode conductivity. The conductivity trend is almost linear and increases with increasing temperature. Slope m was obtained from the linear fit of the data points in Fig. 10 and is used to calculate the activation energy that corresponds to different electro-active regions of the system. Activation energies of bulk, grain boundary, and electrode were found to 0.278, 0.292 and 0.554 eV, respectively. A close inspection of activation energies suggests that, in the given temperature range, bulk (or grains) is less resistive than grain boundary in this material. Grain boundary activation energy, 0.292 eV, is almost the same as calculated in Fig. 4.
Fig. 10
Arrhenius plots of bulk, grain boundary, and sample-electrode contact (extracted from fitting of the data at different temperatures) conductivity

Section2.Heading: AC conductivity analysis
Section2.Para:
The variation of σ ac with frequency at different temperatures for BaMnO3 sample is shown in Fig. 11. Plots of log(σ ac) vs. log(f) show two different features, (i) a frequency independent region at lower frequencies (i.e., up to 10 kHz at 300 K) and (ii) a dispersion region at higher frequencies. The frequency independent plateau/or region corresponding to the DC conductivity which originate as a result of random diffusion of charge carriers through hopping phenomena between neighbor sites [9]. The value of DC conductivity (σ dc) at different temperatures has been obtained from the y-intercept by extrapolating the plateau of log(σ ac) vs. log(f) at lower frequencies. Figure 12 shows the plot of ln(σ dc) as a function of 1000/T. The linear variation of ln(σ dc) vs. 1000/T indicates that DC conductivity obeys Arrhenius equation [19]: 2
$$ \sigma_{\mathrm{dc}} = \sigma_{0}\exp(-E_{\mathrm{a}}/k_{\beta}T) $$ where σ 0 is the pre-exponential factor and parameters in the exponential term have their usual meanings.
Fig. 11
Plots of log(σ ac) vs. log(f) at different temperatures
Fig. 12
Plot of ln(σ dc) as a function of temperature

Activation energy of 0.317 eV±0.058 was calculated from the slope m of linear fit of the data in Fig. 12. This value is in good agreement as compared to the activation energy value calculated from relaxation time vs. 1000/T plot as shown in Fig. 5. In Fig. 11, the plateau at lower frequencies is followed by a frequency dispersion point known as the hopping frequency. The hopping frequency depends upon temperature which shifts towards higher frequency side as temperature of the sample increases. In the second dispersion region at high frequency the conductivity of the material increases rapidly with frequency as well as temperature. This indicates that some hopping type conduction of charge carriers exist in the material and the resultant conductivity follows the universal Jonscher’s power law: 3
$$ \sigma_{\mathrm{ac}} = A\omega^{s} $$ where parameter “A” is weakly temperature dependent constant and “s” is a dimensionless frequency exponent. For polycrystalline and semiconductor materials the value of “s” varies between 0 and 1 [20].

The value of “s” at different temperatures was calculated by linearly fitting the log(σ ac) vs. log(f) plots in the dispersion region at higher frequencies. Obtained values of “s” were then plotted against temperature as shown in Fig. 13.
Fig. 13
Plot of parameter “s” as a function of temperatures

Variation of exponent “s” with temperature (T) is used as a signature of possible electrical conduction mechanism in materials. It is noteworthy from Fig. 13 that exponent “s” decreases as temperature increase, suggesting that correlated barrier hopping (CBH) is the possible conduction mechanism in BaMnO3 sample [21, 22]. In this model conduction in materials takes place through the hopping of carriers over a potential barrier. Such potential barrier exists as a result of two different valance states.

Figure 14 shows plot of ln(σ ac) vs. T −1 at fixed frequencies (such as 25 Hz, 1 kHz, 100 kHz, and 2 MHz). At each frequency ln(σ ac) increases linearly with increasing temperature due to upsurge in thermally activated phenomena of charge carriers. ln(σ ac) also follows Arrhenius equation as given in Eq. (2) for DC conductivity. Activation energy is calculated from slope m of a linear fitting in ln(σ ac) vs. T −1 data points at different frequencies as shown in Fig. 14. Values of these activation energies are tabulated in Table 2. At low frequency of 25 Hz the value of activation energy is 0.305 eV which is almost the same as calculated in Fig. 5 and Fig. 12.
Fig. 14
Plots of ln(σ ac) vs. inverse of temperatures at different frequencies

Table 2 shows that activation energy decreases as frequency of the applied voltage is increased. This indicates that by increasing temperature the charge carries, most probably accumulated at the grain boundaries, acquire sufficient energy to hop to the neighbor site over the barrier which results in the rise in conductivity of our material and is in accordance with our expectations.

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: High temperature conventional mixed oxides route was used to synthesize single phase barium manganate powder. XRD, SEM, and EDX results have verified that the reacted powder is of single phase poly-crystalline material with sintered pellet of highly porous morphology that contains only barium (Ba), manganese (Mn), and oxygen (O) elements, respectively. IS analysis was carried out via complex impedance and complex modulus formalisms and results show that BaMnO3 behave as semiconducting material with NTCR. Grain, grain boundary, and sample-electrode regions in Nyquist and Bode plots were observed to overlap, in the applied frequency domain, suggesting that our material is electrically inhomogeneous in nature. A best fit equivalent circuit model (R g C g)(R gb Q gb)(R e Q e) was employed through which the response from different overlapped electro-active regions were separated. Grain and grain boundary conductivity plots show that grains are more conductive than grain boundaries. The activation energy for conduction at grains and grain boundaries is 0.278 eV and 0.292 eV, respectively. Analysis of ac conductivity as a function of frequency and temperature indicates that correlated barrier hopping (CBH) model is the possible operating conduction mechanism in BaMnO3 sample.

Acknowledgments.Heading: Acknowledgements
Acknowledgments.SimplePara: The authors highly acknowledge the financial support from the Higher Education Commission (HEC), Pakistan.
